clinical_study.brief_title: The Safety and Efficacy of Supraglottic Airway Use in Children
clinical_study.official_title: The Safety and Efficacy of Supraglottic Airway Use in Children

lead_sponsor.agency: Ann & Robert H Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago

clinical_study.source: Ann & Robert H Lurie Children's Hospital of Chicago

brief_summary.textblock: This purpose of this study is to determine the effectiveness, risk factors, and complications associated with use of supraglottic airway devices for primary airway maintenance during routine anesthesia in children.

detailed_description.textblock:
This study aims to understand the efficacy of supraglottic airway (SGA) use in children in a tertiary care Children's Hospital.
Observational data regarding the type of SGA, experience level of practitioner, placement technique, number of placement attempts or placement failure, device failure, and cause of any related peri-operative complications will be prospectively collected.
The data collected in this study will allow the investigators to assess the overall safety and efficacy of SGA use in various medical and surgical procedures performed under general anesthesia in children.

primary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours
primary_outcome.description: Occurrence and reason for supraglottic airway device failure (ie inadequate ventilation, laryngospasm, bronchospasm, etc) will be recorded in addition to conversion to tracheal intubation

secondary_outcome.measure: Ease of Placement of Supraglottic Airway Device
secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Ease of placement of supraglottic airway device ranging from 1 (easy) to 4 (difficult)

secondary_outcome.measure: Multiple Attempts to Place Supraglottic Airway Device
secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours
secondary_outcome.description: change in device, placement method, and provider will be recorded

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours
secondary_outcome.description: the number and type of airway maneuvers performed after device placement and during maintenance will be recorded

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours
secondary_outcome.description: cause and solution for inadequate ventilation will be recorded

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and after surgery, an expected average of 12 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Time period of complication (ie during device placement, maintenance, or removal) and cause of complication (ie. dental injury, light anesthesia, regurgitation, laryngospasm, bronchospasm, aspiration, etc.) will be recorded

secondary_outcome.time_frame: participants will be followed for the duration of anesthesia and 24 hours postoperatively
secondary_outcome.description: Complications noted postoperatively relating to reflex activation of the airway, sore throat, or hoarseness

arm_group.description: Patients will receive a supraglottic airway device as a primary means of ventilation. The following devices may be used: LMA Unique, LMA ProSeal, LMA Supreme, LMA Flexible, Ambu Aura-I, Ambu Aura Once, Air-Q, I-Gel, or other supraglottic airway device. Choice of the device will be clinician dependent and based on the patients body weight per manufacturer guidelines

study_pop.textblock: Pediatric patients undergoing anesthesia with use of a supraglottic airway device as primary means of oxygenation and ventilation.

criteria.textblock:

- Children undergoing anesthesia with use of a supraglottic airway device as a primary means of oxygenation & ventilation
